questions.question: At what stage of mitosis is standard karyotyping performed?
questions.explanation: Standard karyotyping is performed during metaphase because the chromosomes are most condensed and easiest to distinguish at this stage.

questions.question: In cytogenetic terminology, how are the following marked structures designated?
questions.explanation: The short arm of a chromosome (marked as 1) is designated p (for petite), and the long arm (marked as 2) is referred to as q (the next alphabet). Arms of a chromosome: map arm (p) and q arm. In a banded karyotype, each arm of the chromosome is divided into two or more regions bordered by prominent bands. The regions are numbered (e.g., 1, 2, 3) from the centromere outward. Each region is further subdivided into bands and sub-bands, and these are ordered numerically as well. Chromosomal location of a gene: chromosome #7, short arm p. Centromere. Example gene: CFTR. Chromosomal location: long arm q, 7q31.2. Long arm q. U.S. National Library of Medicine: region #3, band #1, sub-band #2.

questions.question: MAOWOMARROW177What aberration occurs when a break occurs at both ends of a chromosome with the fusion ofthe damaged ends?
questions.explanation: A ring chromosome is an aberrant chromosome whose broken ends fuse together to form a ring.Ring chromosomes behave abnormally in meiosis or mitosis and usually result in seriousconsequences. In rare cases, the telomeres at the ends of a chromosome fuse without any loss of186genetic material, which results in a normal phenotype. A ring chromosome is denoted by thesymbol r in human genetics.Ring ChromosomeDeleted GeneticMaterialBreaks inChromosomeFusionUS National Library of MedicineDeleted GeneticMaterialThe following image shows a representative karyotype from a well-differentiated transitional cellcarcinoma of the bladder. The chromosome indicated by 'r' represents a ring chromosome. It results in a chromosome consisting of two short arms only or oftwo long arms.187

questions.question: Which of the following is not associated with the change in genetic material?
questions.explanation: Inversion involves only a rearrangement of the genetic material. There is no change in the geneticmaterial.It occurs as a result of two breaks within a single chromosome. The intervening segment betweenthe breaks gets inverted and reincorporated. It is of two types:• Paracentric - inversion involving only one arm of the chromosome• Pericentric - inversion involving opposite sides of the centromereInversions are often fully compatible with normal development.Transversions are mutations where a purine base pair is replaced by a pyrimidine or vice versa.CentromereBreaks inChromosome.Paracentric InversionReinsertedinversionPiece ofDNAPericentric InversionBreaks inChromosome.CentromereinversionReinsertedPiece ofDNA withCentromereU.S. National Library of Medicine

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect about Down's syndrome?

options.A: Leukemia is the major cause of death in early childhood
options.B: It is the most common chromosomal disorder
options.C: Robertsonian translocations of chromosome 21 are less common
options.D: These children are prone to develop autoimmune diseases

questions.explanation: In Down's syndrome, the major cause of death in infancy and early childhood is cardiac disease,not leukemia.Down's syndrome is the most common chromosomal disorder and is a major cause of mentalretardation. Maternal age is a strong risk factor. This condition can occur by the followingmechanisms:• Majority of cases - meiotic nondisjunction of chromosome 21 in the ovum• Rarely - Robertsonian translocation of the long arm of chromosome 21 to another acrocentricchromosome (e.g., 22 or 14)The clinical features of Down's syndrome include:• Mental retardation• Facial dysmorphism - flat facial profile, oblique palpebral fissures, and epicanthic folds•Congenital heart disease - endocardial cushion defects (ASD, VSD, AV valve malformations)188• Atresias of the esophagus and small bowel• Neuropathologic changes characteristic of Alzheimer's disease - in patients > 40 years• Increased risk of developing acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AML-M7)Predisposition to autoimmune diseases and serious lung infectionsClinical features of Down's syndromeSimiancreaseFlat facialprofileBowelstenosisUmbilicalherniaObliquepalpebral fissureEpicanthal foldAtresia ofesophagusCongenital heartdisease:Most common:Endocardial cushiondefects (ASD, VSD, AVmalformations)OMARROW

questions.question: A 1-year-old child was brought by the mother with complaints of delay in reaching motormilestones. Examination revealed oblique palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, and thefollowing finding. Auscultation revealed a pan-systolic murmur in the left sternal border. Thischild is at risk of developing which of the following?178
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing a single palmar crease (simian crease) are suggestive ofDown's syndrome. It is associated with an increased risk of acute megakaryoblasticleukemia (AML-M7) in affected children < 2 years old.Children with trisomy 21 have a 10 to 20-fold increased risk of developing acute leukemia.• In children < 2 years of age - acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AML-M7) is the most common• In children > 3 years of age - acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most predominant

questions.question: A 7-month-old infant is being evaluated for failure to thrive. Examination reveals low-set ears,a short neck, and the following findings. Auscultation reveals a holosystolic murmur over thepulmonic area. Which of the following statements about this condition is false?

options.B: Karyotype of this child is 47, XY + 18
options.C: It may be associated with horseshoe kidney
options.D: There is increased risk of leukemia

questions.explanation: The images show the index finger overlapping other fingers and rocker bottom feet. This alongwith the clinical features is suggestive of Edward's syndrome. Leukemia is not a feature of thiscondition.It is due to the inheritance of a complete extra copy of chromosome 18 as a result of meioticnondisjunction (47, XY+18). The incidence is 1 in 8000 births.The clinical features of Edward's syndrome include:•• Low-set ears• Short neck189• Overlapping fingers•Congenital heart defects• Renal malformations• Limited hip abduction•Rocker-bottom feet• Prominent occiput• Mental retardation.MicrognathiaNote: Although, rocker bottom feet are seen in both Edward's syndrome and Patau's syndrome,overlapping of fingers is characteristic of Edward's syndrome.

questions.question: Which of the following is not seen in children with Patau syndrome?
questions.explanation: Low set ears are a feature of Patau syndrome, not high set ears.Patau syndrome occurs due to trisomy 13 and is characterized by:• Microphthalmia• Polydactyly•Microcephaly and mental retardation• Cleft lip and palate• Cardiac defects•Umbilical hernia• Renal defects• Rocker-bottom feet (commonly seen in Edwards syndrome also)Patau syndromeSmall headAbsenteyebrowsCleft lip and/orpalateROUndescended orabnormal testesOMARROW190Dysplastic ormalformed earsClenched handsand polydactylyor extra fingers

questions.question: What hypothesis states that one X chromosome, maternal or paternal, is randomlyinactivated during development?
questions.explanation: Lyon's hypothesis states the idea of the inactivation of the X chromosome.It states the following:•Only one of the X chromosomes is genetically active•The other X undergoes heteropyknosis and is rendered inactive (known as Barr body)• Inactivation of either the maternal or paternal X occurs at random among all the cells of theblastocyst on or about day 5.5 of embryonic life• Inactivation of the same X chromosome persists in all the cells derived from each precursor cell.The molecular basis of X inactivation involves the XIST gene.

questions.question: A 25-year-old man was referred for infertility evaluation. On examination, he was tall with alack of body hair. Gynecomastia and micropenis were also noted. Karyotyping analysisrevealed an XXY karyotype. Which of the following statements is not true about thecondition?

options.A: Levels of follicle-stimulating hormone are reduced

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Klinefelter's syndrome. In this condition, thefollicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels are elevated.•The clinical features include:-⚫ Eunuchoid body habitus elongated body and long legs (increased length between the soles andthe pubic bone)• Absence of secondary sexual characteristics - lack of body and facial hair, deep voice• Small atrophic testes• Micropenis• Gynecomastia• Lower IQ, but no mental retardationThe following hormonal variations are seen in these patients:• Elevated FSH• Elevated estradiol•• Low testosterone•Insulin resistance - increased incidence of type 2 diabetesPatients with Klinefelter syndrome are at a higher risk for:• Male breast cancer (20x more common than in normal males)• Extragonadal germ cell tumorsAutoimmune diseases - systemic lupus erythematosus191

questions.question: 180A 16-year-old girl is referred for evaluation of primary amenorrhea and short stature.Examination shows a webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and absent secondary sexualcharacteristics. USG abdomen shows a small uterus and streak ovaries. What is the mostcommon karyotypic abnormality seen in individuals with this condition?

options.B: Isochromosome of the long arm of X chromosome
options.C: Deletion of portions of long arm of X chromosome
options.D: Deletion of ends of long and short arm of X chromosome

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of Turner's syndrome. In this condition, the mostcommon karyotypic abnormality seen is a missing entire X chromosome, seen in more than halfthe cases.Less commonly, structural abnormalities of the X chromosome and mosaicism can also occur. Thecommon feature of the structural abnormalities is to produce partial monosomy of the Xchromosome.In order of frequency, the structural abnormalities of the X chromosome include the following:• An isochromosome of the long arm, 46,X,i(X)(q10), resulting in the loss of the short arm• Deletion of portions of both long and short arms, resulting in the formation of a ringchromosome 46, X,r(X)• Deletion of portions of the short or long arm - 46X,del(Xq) or 46X,del(Xp).The mosaic patients have a 45,XO cell population along with one or more karyotypically normalor abnormal cell types.Few patients with this condition also have Y-chromosome sequences, either as a complete Ychromosome or as fragments of Y chromosomes translocated on other chromosomes. Thesepatients are at a higher risk for the development of a gonadal tumor (gonadoblastoma).

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is not caused by trinucleotide-repeat mutations involvingnon-coding regions?
questions.explanation: Huntington's disease is due to CAG (trinucleotide) repeat mutation in the coding region of thegene, not the non-coding region.Expansion of trinucleotide repeats is an important genetic cause of human disease, particularlyneurodegenerative disorders. The causative mutations are associated with the expansion of astretch of trinucleotides that usually share the nucleotides G and C. In all cases, the DNA isunstable, and an expansion of the repeats above a certain threshold impairs gene function.Expansions affecting noncoding regions will cause a loss of function mutation. They include:• Fragile X syndrome•• Myotonic dystrophy• Friedreich ataxiaExpansions affecting coding regions cause a gain of function mutation. They include:• Spinobulbar muscular atrophy (Kennedy disease)•Huntington disease• Dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy (Haw-River syndrome)• Spinocerebellar ataxia types 1, 2, 3, 6, 7192

questions.question: All of the following are features of fragile X syndrome except:
questions.explanation: Macro-orchidism (large testicles) are seen in fragile X syndrome, not micro-orchidism.Fragile X syndrome is the second most common genetic cause of mental retardation (Downsyndrome being the most common). It is caused by a trinucleotide mutation, characterised bymultiple tandem repeats of the CGG sequence in the familial mental retardation-1 (FMR1) gene. Itis associated with the phenomenon of anticipation, where the disease phenotype worsens overgenerations within a family.The affected males are mentally retarded, with an IQ in the range of 20 to 60.The characteristic phenotypic features include the following:• Long face with a large mandible•• Large everted earsMacro-orchidism⚫ Hyperextensible joints• High arched palate•• Mitral valve prolapseThe given image shows a child suffering from fragile X syndrome.

questions.question: 70 CGG premutations in the FMR1 gene are characteristic of which of the following?
questions.explanation: CGG premutations in the FMR1 gene are characteristic of fragile X ataxia. It is also known asfragile X tremor and fragile X-associated primary ovarian failure.Normally, the FMR1 gene is methylated and silenced, and the number of CGG repeats remains< 55.193However, abnormalities in this gene lead to the accumulation of CGG-containing FMR1 mRNAs,which are toxic to the cell. Depending on the type of mutation, there are 2 distinct syndromes:••Fragile X ataxia syndrome (FXTAS): 55-200 repeats (premutation) which causes gain of functionFragile X syndrome (FXs): 200- 4000 repeats (full mutation) leading to loss of functionMore than half the individuals with FXTAS develop a progressive neurodegenerative syndromestarting in their 6th decade. It is characterized by intention tremors and cerebellar ataxia and mayprogress to Parkinsonism.Option B: Prader-Willi syndrome is associated with deletion of paternal chromosome 15q12 andthe silencing of the maternal allele.Option D: Friedreich ataxia is due to GAA repeat sequences in the noncoding regions.

questions.question: What is the mode of inheritance of Leber hereditary optic neuropathy?
questions.explanation: Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON) is an example of mitochondrial inheritance. It isinherited along the maternal line, as shown in image 4.IIIEThree generation pedigree chart showingthe mitochondrial inheritanceAffectedOMARROWUnaffectedIn diseases following the mitochondrial pattern of inheritance, all children of an affected motherand normal father develop the disease. However, children born to an affected father and a normalmother do not inherit the disease. Hence, only the daughters of the affected mother will transmitthe disease.This is because this condition is due to a mutation in the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which isderived from the maternal mitochondria. The ovum contains several mitochondria, while thespermatozoa have very few mitochondria if present. Hence, the mitochondrial DNA of thezygote is entirely derived from the ovum.LHON is a neurodegenerative disease that manifests as progressive bilateral loss of centralvision. Visual impairment starts between ages 15 and 35, leading eventually to blindness. Otherfeatures include cardiac conduction defects and minor neurologic manifestations.194

questions.question: Which chromosome is involved in myotonic dystrophy?
questions.explanation: Chromosome 19 is involved in myotonic dystrophy.

questions.question: Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in which of the following diseases other thannephrotic syndrome?
questions.explanation: Maltese cross crystals in the urine are seen in Fabry's disease.Urine analysis in Fabry's disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globulesunder polarized light showing a Maltese cross appearance. It can also be seen in nephroticsyndrome.The following image shows Maltese cross casts:Note: Maltese cross appearance is also seen in short-range shotgun wounds and babesiosis.

questions.question: A young male patient as shown below presents with complaints of infertility. On examination,he lacked pubic and facial hair. The genital examination was consistent for a micropenis.Further investigations reveal elevated LH and FSH levels. What is the most common cardiaclesion associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical picture most likely suggests Klinefelter's syndrome. The most common cardiaclesion in this condition is mitral valve prolapse which is seen in nearly half the adults.Systemic manifestations associated with Klinefelter's syndrome:• Gynecomastia•Type 2 diabetes and metabolic syndrome•• Mitral valve prolapse•• Osteoporosis and fractures195• Male infertility••Higher risk for breast cancer, extragonadal germ-cell tumorsSystemic lupus erythematosus

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct statement regarding Huntington's chorea?

options.A: It is a trinucleotide repeat disorder
options.B: There is loss of function type of mutation
options.C: There are abnormal repeats of CUG
options.D: Abnormality is seen due to mutation in chromosome 6183

questions.explanation: Huntington's chorea is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.It is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder. It is caused by CAGtrinucleotide repeats (>40). It occurs due to a gain-of-function (expansion) mutation in thehuntingtin gene on chromosome 4p.The disease shows genetic anticipation and has an early-onset (2-3 decades) if inherited from thefather.Cognitive impairment is an early feature. Pathologically, atrophy of caudate and putamen with exvacuo ventriculomegaly is seen. Decreased acetylcholine leads to dementia and decreased GABAand increased dopamine lead to chorea.Treatment consists of haloperidol and tetrabenazine.Trinucleotide repeat disorders:DiseaseRepeClinical featuresatsFragile X- syndromeCGGMental retardation, large ears, and jaws, macroorchidismin malesMyotonic Dystrophy(chromoCTGMuscle loss, cardiac arrhythsome 19)mia, cataracts, frontal baldingHuntington's diseaseCAGAffective disorderSpinocerebellar ataxia type 1CAGProgressive ataxia, dysarthria,dysmetria.Friedreich's ataxiaGAAProgressive ataxia, dysarthria,hypertrophiccardiomyopathy.

questions.question: Which amongst the following is true about Turner's syndrome?

options.A: Webbing of hands and toes are associated with risk of visceral anomalies
options.B: Noonan syndrome is more associated with cardiac defects
options.C: Absence of neck webbing is associated with higher risk of co-arctation of aorta
options.D: Webbing of neck is associated with higher risk of cardiac anomalies

questions.explanation: In Turner's syndrome, webbing of the neck is associated with a higher risk of cardiac anomalies.The image below summarises the clinical features of Turner's syndrome.196Low posteriorhairlineMicrognathiaShield chestWidely spacednipplesMadelung-deformityTurner syndromeMultiple pigmented neviOMARROWThe image given below shows the webbing of neck.Short stature(increased upper tolower segment ratio)Characteristicsfacial featuresShort andwebbed neckCardiacmalformationsPoor breastdevelopmentCubitus valgusGonadaldysgenesis/ovarian failure(infertility)No menstruationOedema of feetDAILYROUNDSNoonan syndrome is characterised by mutations in the RAS-MAPK pathway. The most commonof these is the PTPN11 which encodes a protein tyrosine phosphatase on chromosome 12.Clinical features include:• Short stature• Short webbed neck• Cystic hygroma• Tall forehead•• Low posterior hairline• Dental malocclusion197Although it shares many clinical features with Turner's syndrome, Noonan syndromeaffects both sexes. It follows an autosomal dominant pattern and it also has a different patternof congenital heart disease, typically involving right-sided lesions.

questions.question: A 5-year-old girl is brought for evaluation of intellectual disability. She also has difficulty inwalking and balancing, and her speech is delayed for her age. The parents also say that shefrequently has sudden bouts of laughter. She is a known case of seizure disorder since the ageof 3. This condition is associated with which of the following chromosomal abnormalities?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Angelman syndrome.
